definition[0]: your opinion or ideas about something, or your attitude towards it
example[0]: The Administration’s thinking changed as the war progressed.
example[1]: Well, to my way of thinking (=in my opinion), they should have done that years ago.
example[2]: He laughed and accused me of wishful thinking (=falsely believing that something will happen just because I want it to).
example[3]: the rich countries’ current thinking on aid
example[4]: the thinking behind the company’s new public relations campaign
note[1]: clear/critical/analytical etc thinking (=a particular way of thinking about things)
example[5]: If it weren’t for Jeff’s quick thinking, Tillie could have been badly hurt.
example[6]: I really needed to do some thinking.
heading[0]: – Meaning 2: when you think about something
example[7]: I’ve had a chance to do some thinking.
example[8]: He was only saved by the quick thinking of two doctors.
example[9]: Over the next two days a lot of hard thinking went into the campaign.
example[10]: Your mother and I have been doing some serious thinking.
example[11]: Above 24,000 feet, the lack of oxygen makes clear thinking almost impossible.
example[12]: Rudi wanted them to practice critical thinking by analysing the world they lived in.
example[13]: Her solution to the problem was an example of good creative thinking.
example[14]: The media has criticized the lack of joined-up thinking in the government’s plans for dealing with a terrorist attack.
definition[2]: a thinking person is intelligent and tries to think carefully about important subjects
